content.text:
# 1788–89 United States presidential election in Massachusetts

Washington/Adams (Federalist)
| title = President
| before_election = Office established
| before_party =
| after_election = George Washington
| after_party = Independent (politician)
}}
The 1788–89 United States presidential election in Massachusetts took place on January 7, 1789, as part of the 1788–1789 United States presidential election to elect the first President. Massachusetts was entitled to 10 electors, with two being appointed by the state legislature and the rest being chosen by state legislature from the two most popular candidates in each U.S. House district. Each elector voted once for President and again for Vice President.
Massachusetts unanimously voted for independent candidate and commander-in-chief of the Continental Army, George Washington, for president and Federalist candidate, former Minister to Great Britain, and delegate to the Continental Congress from Massachusetts John Adams for vice president. The total vote was composed of 4,477 for Federalist electors and 132 for Anti-Federalist electors, all of whom were supportive of Washington. Several candidates of unknown affiliation also received votes.
